item.title: Gallery: Hades 2's Switch 2 Physical Boasts A Stunning Reversible Cover
item.content:encoded:
By the beard of Zeus!

After what felt like an age of early access waiting, Hades II finally arrived as a console exclusive on Switch and Switch 2 back in September. Two months on, and that Switch 2 release has scored a physical edition — what's more, it's a beauty.

We were lucky enough to get our hands on the new box today, and feast our eyes on all of the goodies within (a download code to a digital soundtrack, a 'Character Compendium' booklet, and the full game complete on cart). The nicest surprise of all, however, was the reversible cover art, giving us an option between the standard red banner of a Switch 2 physical, and something more... artsy.

Flipping the cover insert over, you're treated to alternate artwork featuring the game's protagonist, Melinoë, on the front of the box, while a dark and brooding image of Hecate adorns the back.

It's a neat touch, and one that we're sure you'd like to check out for yourselves, so we've assembled the following gallery detailing everything you get in the Hades II Switch 2 physical edition, and a closer look at the all-important art. Enjoy!

The physical Switch 2 edition of Hades II is now available to purchase at most major retailers for £39.99 / $49.99.

item.title: The Best-Selling Xbox 360 Games of All Time
item.content:encoded:
The Xbox 360, the most successful video game console from Microsoft, turns 20 years old on November 22. Over its lifespan, the console saw over 2,000 games released including some of the industries greatest games of all time. While the original Xbox was Microsoft’s first attempt at a mainstream video game console, the Xbox 360 was the one that put the industry on notice. It sold nearly three-and-a-half times more systems than the first Xbox (~85.73 million(M)), and, according to the latest known numbers, has even outsold the Xbox One and Xbox Series X|S combined.

But what games from the 2nd-generation Xbox went on to become major hits? These are the best-selling Xbox 360 games of all time.

Best-Selling Xbox 360 Games Ever

The global data you’ll find below comes from custom data firm Data40, where the provide numbers for the best-selling Xbox 360 games since the system’s launch in 2005. The company says that it’s “high-load parsers scrape the web and marketing analysts process the data to provide up-to-date information for business.” That said, some of the information might not be 100% accurate. Should any discrepancies be found or more accurate information arise, this article will be updated and noted.

10. Grand Theft Auto 4

GTA 4 took players back to Liberty City during one of the most memorable eras in the series. Instead of focusing on wild chaos like earlier games, this one leaned into a more grounded story about Niko Bellic trying to start fresh while getting pulled into one bad situation after another. It felt gritty, personal, and completely different from anything the franchise had done before, which is why so many fans still talk about it today.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 11.1M

9. Halo 3

Halo 3 was the Xbox Live game everyone seemed to be playing. The campaign delivered huge set pieces and emotional moments, while multiplayer kept people up late night after night. Forge mode and Theater mode were ahead of their time and gave players tools no other shooter offered. For a lot of fans, Halo 3 represents the peak of the franchise.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 12.13M

8. Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 arrived with incredible hype and somehow still lived up to it. The campaign had several moments that stuck with players for years, but it was the multiplayer that kept people coming back. Quick scoping battles, chaotic lobbies, and broken loadouts became part of gaming culture. Everyone who played during that era has at least one Modern Warfare 2 story. And most of them, unsurprisingly, involve the most controversial and infamous mission in franchise history.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 13.49M

7. The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim

Skyrim was one of those games you picked up for a quick session and suddenly realized hours had gone by. With dragons flying overhead and a world full of caves, towns, and secrets, every playthrough felt different. Even on Xbox 360, players found creative ways to explore, break, or completely reinvent the game. Almost everyone who touched Skyrim has a unique tale about their time in it.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 13.7M

6. Call of Duty: Black Ops 2

Call of Duty: Black Ops 2 changed things up by jumping into a near future setting and giving players choices that affected the campaign. It also delivered some of the most memorable multiplayer the series has ever had. The maps were tight, the pacing was fast, and the competitive scene was extremely active. Zombies mode continued to grow here and became a nightly ritual for many groups of friends.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 13.7M

5. Call of Duty: Black Ops

The original Call of Duty: Black Ops put players into a Cold War spy thriller with a style that set it apart from other entries in the series. The campaign introduced characters that fans still quote and reference today. Multiplayer became a massive hit thanks to iconic maps and a progression system that kept players hooked. Zombies mode became a lasting obsession for entire friend groups.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 14.55M

4. Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 wrapped up the original Modern Warfare storyline with nonstop action and a campaign that kept the pressure high from beginning to end. Multiplayer continued to dominate Xbox Live with fast matches and an enormous amount of customization. Whether players preferred MW2 or MW3, almost everyone spent time in this one when it launched.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 14.72M

3. Minecraft: Xbox 360 Edition

Minecraft on Xbox 360 brought the world of crafting and block building to console players in the best way possible. It quickly became a favorite for families and groups of friends thanks to its simple controls and endless possibilities. To add to it, it allowed friends to play online together in an easier way than the original PC version. Many players who grew up during the 360 era still think of this version as their first real introduction to Minecraft. Fast-forward years later, and Minecraft is the most successful video game of all time with over 350 million copies sold across all platforms.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 21M

2. Grand Theft Auto 5

GTA 5 launched on the Xbox 360 in September 2013 and immediately became one a top-selling game. The three-character structure felt fresh, and the world of Los Santos was filled with detail and personality. Even after finishing the story, players kept coming back to explore, find secrets, and try new things. The early days of GTA Online also started here, giving the game a long life on the console. As of October 2025, global sales of the game have hit 220M, putting it behind only Minecraft.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 22.95M

1. Kinect Adventures

Kinect Adventures was bundled with the Kinect, which meant almost every Kinect owner tried it at some point. It offered simple but energetic minigames that got people moving and laughing, and it was one of the few games that actually showed what the Kinect could do. It worked well for families and parties and became a surprisingly memorable part of the Xbox 360 era.

Estimated Xbox 360 Sales: 24M

item.title: Black Ops 7 Aim Assist Strength Will Be Increased Soon
item.content:encoded:
In a new video uploaded on social media, Treyarch revealed that Black Ops 7’s aim assist strength will be ‘increased over range’ very soon. This follows a period of monitoring based on community feedback that stressed that the aim assist felt too loose compared to previous games.

This is in addition to a bunch of other tweaks coming in, such as a reduction in the efficacy of the Drone Pod field upgrade, damage tuning for Hardcore modes, and an increase in the visible range of the minimap in multiplayer.

Black Ops 7’s Spongy Aim Assist is Being Adjusted

In the clip uploaded earlier today on social media, Treyarch confirmed that aim assist is being adjusted soon:

Aim assist is a big conversation out there; we have been closely monitoring that conversation, and of course, looking at our internal data. We’re fairly happy with where we’re at, but we will be making some very nuanced changes and slightly increasing aim assist strength over range ahead of season one.

The team will also perform some fine-tuning of spawns, adjusting spawn logic ‘across the board’ and attacking points of contention on particular maps that have less-than-desirable spawns in certain game modes, including Hardpoint.

Black Ops 7’s aim assist came under fire at launch, even from some of the most capable Call of Duty League pro players. It was dubbed ‘insane and not in a good way’ by Shotzzy, potentially the winningest Call of Duty player in the world right now.

All this is lumped into some major changes, such as Activision’s teams unlocking the ‘Endgame’ mode, which exists at the end of Black Ops 7’s campaign, and making it available universally. This means you no longer need to complete the campaign to access it.

Black Ops 7 hasn’t had a terrible launch, but it’s certainly struggling against some tough competition in Battlefield 6, the best-selling shooter in years, and ARC Raiders, the most successful extraction shooter ever.

A look at the mystifying realm of Avalon.

Eclipse Glow Games has released a new gameplay trailer and screenshots for Arthurian legend-inspired fantasy action adventure game Tides of Annihilation dubbed “Break the Mirror.”

“We’ve created a world that reimagines Arthurian Legend where themes of courage, loyalty, and heroism intertwine with an epic story set in a strange-yet-familiar setting that will test the mettle of true gamers and push the genre forward,” said Kun Fu, Lead Game Producer at Eclipse Glow Games. “We are thrilled to share the next chapter of Gwendolyn’s journey, and this is only the beginning.”

  • ❮
  • ❯

Here are the latest details:

  • What is Tides of Annihilation?
    • Tides of Annihilation is an action adventure game set in a modern-day, invasion-fractured London and mysterious otherworld realm, where the lone survivor, Gwendolyn, seeks the Holy Grail to rescue her sister and restore the world.
  • Who are the main characters featured in this new trailer?
    • The trailer features Gwendolyn, the main character in the game. She faces off against the powerful shape-shifting witch Tyronoe and is assisted by spear-wielding Sir Lamorak, a Knight of the Roundtable.
  • What is the story behind this new Tides of Annihilation Trailer?
    • As Gwendolyn continues her quest to rescue her sister and restore humanity, she will encounter different stories and conflicts behind Knights of the Roundtable and the evils behind this otherworldly invasion. This includes uncovering the truth behind Sir Lamorak, whose suffering is caused by the witch Tyronoe. This leads Gwendolyn to the church ruins where the fight takes place with Tyronoe.
  • When Lamarok comes to help the main character Gwendolyn, it looks like the player is able to control Lamorak. Is this a new part to the Knights system in the game?
    • One of the key unique features of the game is the Knights System where Gwendolyn can summon and command spectral knights to attack during battle. Part of this Knights System is being revealed for the first time in the new trailer called the Dual Frontline Battle System. This system shows the ability to control both Gwendolyn and Lamorak to simultaneously attack Tyronoe and break down her magical barriers.
  • How many Knights will be featured in the game and will we see other named Knights of the Roundtable like Gawain or Lancelot?
    • Through her quest for the Holy Grail, Gwendolyn will be able to find several knights to summon and command in the game, including notable Knights of the Roundtable from Arthurian mythology. More details including the number and names of Knights will be disclosed in the future, please stay tuned!
  • The main boss Tyronoe creates a mirror-like Folded Realm in the trailer- can you explain what is a Folded Realm in the game?
    • The Folded Realm is a mysterious story element in Tides of Annihilation and Gwendolyn will encounter different types of these otherworldly realms throughout the game. Tyronoe is one of few characters that can travel between the human world and this Mirror Folded Realm she creates, and can make use of powerful magic energies from this Mirror Realm. More details of the Folded Realm will be revealed soon!
  • When is Tides of Annihilation launching on PC and consoles?
    • Tides of Annihilation will be releasing on PC, Xbox Series X|S, and PlayStation 5 consoles. A release date has not been announced at this time.

Tides of Annihilation will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam and Epic Games Store. A release date has yet to be announced.

item.title: CoD: Black Ops 7 Aim-Assist Changes And Weapon Balancing Are Coming In Season 1 Update
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Treyarch has released its first post-launch Dev Talk video to reveal some major changes the studio is preparing for the launch of Season 1 next month. This discusses the community feedback regarding Black Ops 7's aim-assist, weapon balancing, and more.

Black Ops 7's assault rifles feel really powerful in multiplayer, while most of the guns in the submachine class have struggled to feel viable. Treyarch associate design director Matt Scronce confirms that a buff is coming across the entire submachine gun class. Scronce says no plans are made for adjustments to the marksman rifles or snipers, but the team is monitoring the data.

"The overall goal with those weapons in Black Ops 7 is that they are a bit more present without being too dominant," Scronce says.

The developer is also aware of the community debate around Black Ops 7's aim assist, which features reduced rotational aim-assist compared to recent Call of Duty games. "We have been closely monitoring that conversation and looking at our internal data," Scronce says. The developer also reveals the studio is "fairly happy" with where the game's aim-assist is at, but there will be a slight increase to aim-assist strength at range. This change will arrive sometime ahead of the Season 1 update.

Additionally, Treyarch's planned update includes spawn adjustments for Hardpoint, Free-For-All, and Team Deathmatch modes. A nerf is also coming for the game's overpowered Drone Pod field upgrade.

The developer announced that Endgame mode, which players can unlock after completing the campaign, will be available to everyone starting on November 21. Players who unlocked Endgame naturally by beating the campaign will receive a variety of rewards, including XP tokens, GobbleGums, and more.

For Zombies changes, Treyarch design director Kevin Drew discusses the difficulty level of the boss fight for Ashes of the Damned. The developer says it was designed to be challenging, but it is more difficult than intended. Adjustments will be made to the barnacle spawns needed to help Ol' Tessie, so players can spend less time repairing the Wonder Vehicle and more time driving. The developer says it's slowing down the speed boss's missile barrage attack.

Nuketown arrived to Black Ops 7 today, and this is a new 2025 variant of Treyarch's classic map. Season 1 of Black Ops 7 begins in December, which will add the game's first battle pass, Warzone integration, additional maps, and more.

item.title: Arc Raiders A Lay Of The Land Quest Guide
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

You'll need to take a trip to the Spaceport map to complete the A Lay of the Land quest in Arc Raiders. This quest tasks you with finding multiple items in a single trip to the map, so you'll want to come prepared to make a long trek and survive for quite some time. Let's take a look at everything you'll need to do to get this quest wrapped up.

Knowing that you'll have a lot of traveling and surviving to do on Spaceport for the A Lay of the Land quest, we'd recommend you bring guns you're comfortable with, as well as plenty of healing items. Additionally, it's a great idea to bring in an augment that has a safe pocket, as you'll need to extract with a specific item to complete the quest back in Speranza.

When you're ready to head out and begin A Lay of the Land, follow the guide below.

Where to find the shipping notes in the foreman's office

The first objective requires you to collect some shipping notes in the foreman's office at the Jiangsu Warehouse. This POI is located on the northwestern side of the Spaceport map. It's not usually a very busy spot, but keep your eyes open for nearby raiders nonetheless.

Once inside, you'll notice there's really not much to this warehouse. Simply head upstairs into the office to locate the shipping notes on a desk in plain sight.

With that out of the way, you'll have a slightly more dangerous location to head to next, so get prepared and set off when you're ready.

Locate the scanners on the upper floor of Control Tower A6

The second objective requires you to seek out a LiDAR Scanner on the upper floor of Control Tower A6, which is located in the middle of the Spaceport map. This area is among the most contested locations on the map, meaning you'll want to approach it with the mindset that a fight could break out at any moment.

There are a few ways to enter the first room of the Control Tower A6, but for the sake of this guide, we need to enter from the front left side.

Once you enter the Control Tower A6 building, walk to the door straight ahead. Be mindful that there is sometimes a turret in here, so take it out if necessary. Open the door, then take the stairs all the way up to the next floor.

When entering the next floor, take an immediate right.

Take another right to wrap around to a cubicle.

Here, you'll find the LiDAR Scanner. Interact with the objective to cause the scanner to fall out, then be sure to pick it up and add it to your inventory.

Lastly, you'll need to extract with the LiDAR Scanner and return it to Shani in Speranza to complete the quest. As such, you'll want to head to whichever extraction point is closest to your location and play things cautiously until you can get out. If you brought an augment with a safe pocket, make sure the LiDAR Scanner is placed in it in case you don't make it out. It's not that we don't believe in you; we're just looking out for you, raider.

item.title: New 007 First Light Trailer Shows Off Bond’s Stylish Wheels
item.content:encoded:
Today's Xbox Partner Preview event showcased 16 games and announcements, one of them being a new trailer for IO Interactive's upcoming James Bond game, 007 First Light. Though it wasn't a huge new showcase of gameplay, a deep dive into the game's mechanics, or even a behind-the-scenes look at the game's development, it did highlight a key element of any James Bond video game: the car that Bond drives.

The short, fifty-second trailer shows off Bond's Aston Martin Valhalla, a stunning car even without all of the special agent gadgetry that Q details in his narration of the trailer.

"Inspired by the groundbreaking Aston Martin Valkyrie and infused with advanced Formula 1 technologies, the Valhalla showcases aerodynamic mastery, race-derived engineering, and exquisite craftsmanship," writes IO Interactive senior global communications manager, Yann Roskell, in an Xbox Wire post. "Limited to just 999 units worldwide, this supercar sets the standard for automotive innovation, showcasing unparalleled speed and precision."

Okay, perhaps it would have been better to get a deeper look at gameplay or some more insight into how the game was made, similar to what we saw in September during a State of Play presentation. But a James Bond game will live and die by how well it truly captures the allure of the character that has captivated fans for decades.

Bond's taste for gadgets, clothes, and of course, cars, are all mixed in with that allure, so it makes sense that IO Interactive would put something like this together to further display how it is trying to capture the essence of James Bond.

That said, hopefully we don't have to go too long before getting a more detailed dive into what we can expect from the game ahead of its release on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X/S on March 27, 2026.

item.title: Demeo x Dungeons & Dragons: Battlemarked Brings Simplified TTRPG Combat To The Forgotten Realms
item.content:encoded:
I'm a big fan of Dungeons & Dragons, and when I can't find the time to get a group of friends together, I'm always down to try different experiences that seek to recreate the experience. The latest of these is Demeo x Dungeons & Dragons: Battlemarked. A tabletop experience where abilities are replaced by cards as you go dungeon crawling through the Forgotten Realms, but where does it successfully recreate the experience, and where does it falter?

Battlemarked is, as the name would suggest, a new title in the Demeo series of turn-based RPGs that leans into recreating the feeling of moving miniatures around a board and taking on waves of enemies as you dive deeper into interesting dungeons. This time around, the game has received a Dungeons & Dragons coat of paint with character classes reflecting those from the TTRPG, cards of popular abilities and spells, and the campaigns are now set in the Forgotten Realms.

At launch, the game will release with two Campaigns, Embers of Chaos and Crown of Frost. In my time previewing the game, I dove into Embers of Chaos. Here, the surrounding areas of Neverwinter are in turmoil, and stress is rising between groups of humans and elves as strange attacks are on the rise.

Through the early moments of the campaign, you'll find yourself fighting off bandits, saving the town of Thundertree, enjoying a drink at a local tavern, and diving deep into a mushroom-infested cave system. While there's certainly a number of name drops and references, it's still very clear this is a combat and tactics forward game, and not as much into building any kind of vast story.

There's no worry with not creating that experience, it's just good to make sure you don't go in expecting that.

Battlemarked Gameplay Works Like A Board Game

Demeo x Dungeons & Dragons: Battlemarked leans heavily into the turn-based combat and simplified action economy of Dungeons & Dragons. Starting a new area, your party will appear on the edge of the map, and you'll move them one by one, each character being able to take two actions per turn.

You can move, make a simple attack, or use any of the different items or ability cards at your disposal. With Battlemarked, all of the cards have a D&D theme with simple tweaks like Fire Arrows, as well as Lay on Hands and Blinkstrike. Your hand is limited to 10 cards, but as you take out enemies, you'll slowly earn more cards. It's pretty unlikely you'll ever run out.

This action economy did take me a bit to work out, because moving took an action, but using an attack ability could also move you and let you do an attack. Trying to keep the party together, but also dealing damage efficiently was a bit of a puzzle in itself (and one that I definitely lost a few times.)

When you are ready to attack an opponent, you'll be presented with a die to roll. While it is a D20, the dice you roll is made up of a skull for a miss, a single sword for hit, and two swords for a Critical hit. I'm someone who likes seeing high numbers on dice, so it wasn't as appealing to see the attack dice symbol-based, but it definitely speeds up the game. What was incredibly satisfying in the diorama world of the game is that rolling the dice is physics-based, letting you grab and throw the dice, and watching it bounce all over the terrain.

There are skill checks where you use a D20, these pop up during conversation or when you stumble across random events in a map, that do rely on your character stats. For the most part, you'll be rolling the Attack Dice though.

Battlemarked really has the visuals of Dungons & Dragons down, as someone who plays (way too much) D&D, though it felt like a lot of these systems were a bit too simplified for me. You have a good chance to hit, but you won't always, and your characters' attack stats are all static. It would have been awesome to see some varying damage stats to create more scenarios where you'd go for a risky attack to hope for a high damage roll to finish off an enemy.

Randomization & Replayability

When combat is a bit too tough and you fall in battle, you'll get to restart from the beginning of the floor, but the enemies present and their locations will be randomized. This is a fun addition, meaning that no matter how much the environment you move through might be the same, the progression of combat will always be different.

There's further replayability to be had in the game in playing with different people, what class you choose, and how you choose to upgrade your character. Do you prefer that your Paladin takes less damage on low health, or that there is less chance for Poison damage?

Battlemarked Offers A D&D-lite Combat Experience

From my time with Battlemarked so far, I've enjoyed the story as it has been laid out, and the visual experience perfectly demonstrates a high-quality game with terrain and miniatures.

I do wish that the combat wasn't so dialed back, but there is a lot of replayability in the layout of enemies in a dungeon and how you best use the cards available to you. With how every part of the game is static numbers and grid-based movement, even when not in active combat, the experience honestly felt closer to my recent experiences with HeroQuest.

If you're interested in getting online with friends and throwing some dice in a strategic setting, Demeo x Dungeons & Dragons: Battlemarked is a fun experience, even more so with the different references that you'll run into. If the simplified combat or very light storytelling isn't for you, then you might need to seek your adventure elsewhere.

item.title: Windows handhelds are getting the new Xbox Full Screen Experience tomorrow
item.content:encoded:
Tom Warren

is a senior editor and author of Notepad, who has been covering all things Microsoft, PC, and tech for over 20 years.

Microsoft will start rolling out its new Xbox Full Screen Experience (FSE) to Windows-based handhelds on November 21st. The full screen mode for the Xbox app originally shipped on the Xbox Ally devices last month, providing a more console-like navigation experience on top of Windows 11.

While Microsoft released a preview to MSI Claw models last month, it’s now making the Xbox Full Screen Experience generally available to all Windows-based handhelds. Microsoft is also expanding Xbox FSE “to more Windows 11 PC form factors through the Xbox and Windows Insider programs soon.”

The Xbox FSE doesn’t load the full Windows desktop or a bunch of background processes, freeing up more memory for games. It’s essentially not loading the Explorer shell and saving around 2GB of memory by suppressing all the unnecessary parts of a typical Windows 11 installation.

If you decide to enable Xbox FSE on your handheld or PC, it will launch you straight into the Xbox PC app at boot, which includes all of your PC games from the Microsoft Store, Battle.net, Steam, and other storefronts. There’s also a Game Bar for navigating between games and launchers, and a task view that’s designed to be more handheld-friendly.

To turn on Xbox FSE on a compatible handheld, go to Settings > Gaming > Full screen experience, then select Xbox as your home app.

item.title: Monster Handgun Wrecking Everyone In Arc Raiders Has Been Put In Nerf Jail
item.content:encoded:
Arc Raiders got a fresh set of patch notes for its 1.3.0 update this morning. The update includes a variety of changes across the board, but perhaps most important are the changes to a two-shot pistol that’s been causing havoc and devastation for anyone on the receiving end of its twin barrels. Here are all the changes impacting in-game weapons and items:

The Venator gets ‘re-tuned’ and explosions are less explosive

A blue rare gun, the Venator is a girl’s best friend as a sidearm and a seriously reliable primary weapon if you like maining pistols. That might change a bit as the gun was previously “capable of outgunning full squads using close range weapons,” according to the patch notes.

The other notable change here is that explosions have been tweaked. To be honest, I kinda saw this one coming as it’s been pretty damn easy lately to take out the larger Arc threats with things that go boom. The most significant of these changes sees the Hullcracker launcher, great for taking down Arc, requiring more accuracy, while explosions on large enemies “deal a bit less damage,” as Embark puts it.

The cost of ammo for the Hullcracker has also shifted, and arguably not for the better. Whereas you could snag a pack of 10 from the in-game traders for 6,000 Coins, you’ll now get 6 launcher ammo for 4,500.

As one comment thread on Reddit discusses, this might have the run-on effect of seeing fewer people rushing the Arc Queen as they’ll be a little less equipped, and with weaponry that requires some more careful aiming.

Embark takes aim at bugs and wall-glitching, but some issues remain

Arc Raiders’ performance is mostly reliable, but folks found some unfortunate bugs that affected bullet collision, as well as exploits that allow players to glitch into rooms that are otherwise locked.

The update brings improvements to those bullet issues on the map Blue Gate. It’s a nice start, but I know I’ve seen similar issues elsewhere, too. The patch notes detail “railing props [that] mistakenly blocked bullets” but say that “shots now pass through as expected.” Across the other maps, some other player collision issues were touched up.

Players have also been exploiting some wall-glitching, allowing them to enter locked rooms without keys or to hide in unreachable ambush spots. Dam Battlegrounds has had an exploit that allowed access to the Control Tower fixed, while a specific wall in Spaceport that players were glitching into to jump unsuspecting players will no longer allow for this.

Still, I’ve seen all sorts of locked doors bypassed by folks, not just the ones addressed by this patch. Hopefully there’ll be less of this.

But perhaps the most frustrating movement issue occurs when trying to access an escape hatch while in a downed-but-not-out status. Normally, until you’re fully knocked out, you can crawl your way to an escape as the game lets you activate the elevator or escape hatch terminals while you’re down. But as documented well in this video on Reddit, most hatches seem to sit atop a slope that can’t be climbed while crawling.

It’s hard to tell if this is intentional or an oversight. But it’s clearly been a frustrating experience for those who’ve tried to make a daring last-minute escape via a hatch, only to find out they can’t crawl over a hump.

Good news (maybe) for duck fans

Lastly, update 1.3.0 will fill your Raider’s room with more rubber ducks, letting them spill over the floor if you have enough in your stash.

It’s cute! But if you ask me, those ducks aren’t valuable enough to extract with and are otherwise too pointless for me to have them taking up room in my stash. So fear not, any rubber ducks I come across are deliberately left behind on the battlefield. You’re welcome.

item.title: I Was Interested In ‘Furry May Cry’ Until I Found Out It Might Be Using AI
item.content:encoded:
Today’s Xbox Partner Preview had a bunch of big announcements and trailers like a new look at the upcoming 007 First Light and the reveal of a follow-up to Vampire Survivors, but one of the surprise standouts for me was Zoopunk, a new action game by F.I.S.T.: Forged In Shadow Torch developer TiGames, starring a bunch of anthropomorphic animals in a sort of dark, science-fiction post-apocalypse. However, as more news is trickling out, it’s beginning to look like the game might be using AI generation tools, and that has deflated my interest.

Zoopunk‘s fast-paced combat looks slick and stylish, but maybe a little stiff at first glance. I’m curious to see how it feels when the controller’s in my hands. Growing up playing Devil May Cry made me very picky about character action games in the PS2 era, so if one doesn’t feel good to play, I tend to bounce off of it very quickly. But what TiGames showed in the first trailer has potential.

However, what didn’t come up during the Xbox showcase was that Zoopunk was also used as part of a Stable Diffusion AI asset generation demo earlier this year. The video, which is currently “unlisted” on the game’s YouTube channel, shows a user drawing simplistic equipment designs, which are then used to generate an in-game model. At the moment, it’s unclear if this is integrated into the game itself, or if Zoopunk was just used as a demo for the AI model. An NVIDIA announcement from earlier this year also names the game as using AI-powered NPCs. We’ve reached out to TiGames for comment on the situation and will update this story if we hear back.

Generative AI is creeping into video games more and more over recent years, with several executives at big companies insisting it should become the norm within the industry. Despite this, generative AI has become a legal battleground as these models are being trained on copyrighted works.

Psychological horror game with music by Akira Yamaoka.

Publisher Apogee Entertainment and developer Trigger Happy Interactive have released psychological survival horror game Total Chaos for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam and Microsoft Store for $24.99, the companies announced.

“Total Chaos began for me almost two decades ago when the original mod became my first real step into creating a world of my own,” said Trigger Happy Interactive head Sam Prebble in a press release. “I never imagined I’d return to Fort Oasis and rebuild it as a full standalone release on PC and consoles. I’m grateful to everyone who helped bring it to this moment, especially the teams at Apogee, Atari, and Infogrames. See you on the island. Listen carefully to the voice you follow.”

Apogee Entertainment executive producer Jeron Moore added, “Total Chaos is Apogee’s first step into survival horror and a full-circle moment for Sam, whose early love for classics like DOOM, Duke Nukem 3D, S.T.A.L.K.E.R., and the horror genre at large helped inspire this original vision. What began as a total conversion mod has grown into a faithful and expanded remake. Our creative bond from Turbo Overkill made it a privilege to support him again and ensure Total Chaos delivers a truly landmark horror experience.”

Guest composer Akira Yamaoka said, “I am truly honored to have taken part in this collaboration with Total Chaos. Within the chaos lies a hidden silence—an invisible world that cannot be captured by words, but only expressed through sound. It is an experience like a journey where unseen landscapes are felt through the ears rather than seen by the eyes. I hope you enjoy it.”

Here is an overview of the game, via Apogee Entertainment:

About

Descend into Total Chaos, a gripping terrormare that blurs the line between reality and madness.

Once a bustling haven for coal miners, Fort Oasis is now a crumbling wasteland, its eerie silence broken only by a cryptic radio transmission beckoning you toward the island’s heart—the forsaken mines. But as you delve deeper into the island’s desolation, the path forward becomes twisted and uncertain, unraveling unsettling truths hidden in the encroaching darkness.

Scavenge for scraps and craft makeshift weapons to defend yourself against the horrors that lurk in the shadows. Unearth fragments of forgotten lives scattered across the island and piece together the chilling mystery of Fort Oasis’s demise. Every discovery brings you closer to a truth that threatens to shatter your sanity.

Key Features

  • Immersive Atmosphere – Explore the decayed ruins of Fort Oasis across nine harrowing chapters, each drenched in dread, plunging you deeper into its oppressive, decaying world.
  • Environmental Storytelling – Uncover the island’s darkest secrets and confront your own fractured past through cryptic notes, haunting visuals, and unsettling encounters.
  • Crafting for Survival – Build and upgrade weapons using scavenged materials to stand a chance against the relentless terrors stalking you.
  • Face Nightmarish Foes – Engage against horrific creatures, each with their own deadly behaviors and strategies.
  • Resource Management – Navigate a deep inventory system where every item matters—your survival hinges on careful choices, crafting the perfect weapon, and quick thinking on the fly.
  • A Haunting Original Soundtrack – Total Chaos features a new original theme and end credits track by legendary Silent Hill composer Akira Yamaoka, joined by original Total Chaos mod composers Jason Dagenet and William Braddell, and Apogee’s music team, Chipper Hammond, Tim Stoney, and Mathieu Hallouin. Together, they’ve crafted an ambient, nightmare-inducing soundscape that blurs the line between music and madness.

Originally conceived as an award-winning total conversion mod, Total Chaos has been fully reimagined into a standalone terrormare, amplifying its chilling atmosphere and relentless tension for a new generation of players.

As part of the November Xbox Partner Preview, developer Cybernetic Walrus announced that Roadside Research is coming to Xbox and will be a day-one release for Game Pass. What is Roadside Research? Few things in life are certain, but I feel confident in saying you probably won't guess the hook for this game.

What even is Roadside Research?

Roadside Research is a 1-4 player co-op gas station simulator. Simulator-type games are everywhere these days, but this one differentiates itself because you play as an alien. More specifically, you're an undercover alien who tries to act like a human and do human-like things that a gas station attendant would do like stocking shelves and assisting customers. "Just don't get caught," reads a line from the description.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Now Playing: Roadside Research | Official Reveal Trailer

All the while, players are trying to gather intelligence on humans in preparation for an upcoming alien invasion. "If you arouse too much suspicion, the government will show up, jeopardizing your Earthly mission," the description adds.

This is a comedic game, as you can immediately tell by watching the trailer. The aliens in the game are the classic little green men, and to blend in, you must create what you deem to be a human-looking face mask--but it doesn't have to be any good, really.

Game Pass gets a lot of big-name launches, and one of the perks of a subscription service is that you can sample titles you might not otherwise rush to buy outright. If you're curious about Roadside Research but not sure you want to buy it, Game Pass seems like a pretty good avenue.

During the daytime, players will work as gas station attendants and do their best to blend in and be "normal." At night, players will take what they learned about humans and use that information to upgrade the gas station to attract more humans, and thereby gather even more intelligence about them.

Roadside Research is set for release in Q1 2026 (January 1-March 31, 2026) and will come to Game Pass Ultimate at launch for Xbox and PC. It's not immediately clear if the game is also coming to PlayStation.

A free demo is available already on Steam. It's attracted a lot of interest and attention on Steam, where it's landed on more than 300,000 user wishlists, with more than 260,000 people playing the demo as of early October.

What else has Cybernetic Walrus made?

Cybernetic Walrus is an independent developer that aims to "redefine how players connect with virtual worlds," and specifically mentions on its website that it makes simulation-type games. Before Roadside Research, the studio made the horror game Order 13, in which players must navigate a dark and scary warehouse as they take on packing orders and try to keep their cat alive. The team also made Does It Stack, a physics-based mixed-reality puzzle game for Meta Quest VR. Additionally, Cybernetic Walrus developed the futuristic anti-gravity racing game Antigravitator.

You don't have to pay extra for Game Pass... for now

In October, Microsoft announced a dramatic Xbox Game Pass price increase for Game Pass Ultimate and PC Game Pass, along with some changes to the other tiers. The new price for Game Pass Ultimate soared by 50% to $30/month. However, most major retailers are not going with the new price, at least not yet, so you can still get Game Pass Ultimate for $20/month or $60 for three months on Amazon and many other stores.

item.title: Erosion Is an Open World Roguelite Spaghetti Western Shooter Where Your Deaths Advance Time and Bring Consequences
item.content:encoded:
Polish indie developer Plot Twist has unveiled its new open world roguelite game, Erosion, at the Xbox Partner Preview, and it was certainly among the most interesting titles there.

In Erosion, players find themselves in a distant future where a mysterious, sentient rock formation known as the Pillar is consuming civilization, bit by bit. They must descend into the Pillar and battle through chaotic, fully destructible dungeons to get one step closer to saving the protagonist’s daughter or losing her to time itself forever. Every decision alters the course of the story, and every death reduces the time available.

The game can be roughly split into two parts:

  • Dungeon runs, where the focus is on fast-paced, twin-stick roguelite combat in procedural dungeons.
  • The Overworld, a handcrafted, open world, spaghetti western environment dedicated to exploration, quests, and meta-progression.

Erosion was built with a “low voxel” aesthetic, enabling full physics-driven environmental destructibility. Players will encounter a diverse range of biomes, both above ground (deserts, swamps, ancient cities) and below ground in dungeons, each presenting unique atmospheric and enemy challenges. The game features an extensive arsenal of weapons, active/passive skills, and "orbitals" that the player can equip to deal with enemies. Boss design draws inspiration from classic arcade games (Snake, DDR, Pong, Tetris), sometimes blending bullet hell and puzzle elements. Erosion even features side activities such as poker, racing, sand fishing, and hunting.

The game's defining feature, however, is undoubtedly the time jump mechanic. Dying advances time, irreversibly altering relationships and quest outcomes, with branching consequences. Decisions like which factions to help, quests to complete, or bosses to fight have persistent effects; some villages might be taken over by factions or descend into anarchy depending on player actions. Eventually, players can unlock the ability to travel backward in time, undo previous choices, and try alternative timelines, letting them explore different outcomes and ultimately fix eroding timelines.

Plot Twist is planning to kick off early access in Spring 2026 for PC (Steam, Xbox on PC, and Game Pass), with console versions to follow. The developer said the early access period is expected to be short but will include rolling content updates, such as new biomes, skills, and timelines. The devs also plan to explore two-person cooperative gameplay and robust post-launch content inspired by successful roguelites like Dead Cells.

item.title: Here's an unedited bossfight video from Tides Of Annihilation to sate your hunger for Arthurian witch murder
item.content:encoded:
Devil May Cry me a frozen river, Tyronoe

Biff! Smash! Spear to the groin! Asteroid to the jaw! It must be a new gameplay video for Tides Of Annihilation, the Arthurian fantasy action game from Eclipse Glow Games that's out to steal either Stellar Blade, Final Fantasy XVI or Bayonetta's lunch - do me a favour and pick one, because I can't decide. I can't stop comparing this game to things. I think there's something wrong with me. Help.

The hoity-toity Englishness of it all is somewhat Bayonetta (minus the humour), but the ally-summoning mechanics remind me more of FF16, while lead character Gwendolyn is from the same school of improbably clean-cut beauty as Stellar Blade's Eve. She's perhaps a bit more grizzled than Eve, possibly because she keeps letting witches hit her in the face with small planets.

The video shows us a boss battle against one of those witches, Tyronoe. It appears unedited, so we can get a sense of the ebb and flow of the game's fancier throwdowns. The boss alternates between human-scale punching, valkyrie bombardments from the other side of energy barriers, and a tricksy little moment where she warps through a frozen lake's mirrored surface and starts battering you from inside the reflection. Fortunately, Gwendolyn teams up mid-fight with a Knight of the Roundtable, Lamorak, whose twisty javelin proves super-effective against the hag.

A barrage of background trivia from the announcement post: based in China, Eclipse Glow number 100 developers and have people who've previously worked on Yakuza, For Honor, Assassin's Creed, Persona, and Prince of Persia.

Tides Of Annihilation will be 30 hours long, and will have around 30 bosses. Some of the enemies are big enough to be levels, a la Fumito Ueda. Yes, that is Jennifer English of Baldur's Gate 3 fame voicing Gwendolyn. The game is set across post-apocalyptic London and mythical Avalon, and they may have got the bus routes wrong.

item.title: Godfall Developers Reveal New Game Armatus, a Third-Person Action Game Set in a Messed Up Paris
item.content:encoded:
Today's Xbox Partner Showcase opened with a brand new game reveal I certainly didn't see coming: it's called Armatus, and it's seemingly being made by the developers of Godfall.

Armatus is a new third-person roguelite shooter set in a fictionalized version of Paris that's looking...pretty messed up. An event called The Vanishing has effectively caused the end of the world, and you're some sort of masked warrior roaming around and fighting demons. That's really all we know for now: the trailer gave us a look at a lot of combat and some pretty cool monster designs.

In an Xbox Wire post, we learned a little more: after the end of the world, four members of something called the Armatus meet and summon the player to fight on their behalf and get them sent to heaven. You're searching for something called The Sunless Gate along The Scoured Path, which is a constantly changing road through a broken Paris, with procedurally-spawned rooms, enemy compositions, and rewards.

If you've forgotten everything about Counterplay's last game, Godfall, here's a refresh: Godfall was an action RPG that came out in 2020, initially just for PlayStation and PC but later for Xbox as well. It was described at the time as a "looter-slasher", heavily focused on finding and collecting better and better gear, and that admittedly had an awful lot of cool-looking weapons to collect. Unfortunately it received pretty mixed reviews, including from us, getting an IGN 6/10. As our reviewer put it then: "Godfall can be an enjoyable and lovely gear-based action game while it lasts, but the repetition of its missions wears thin before the end of its campaign, and even thinner in the endgame afterward." Hopefully Armatus fairs better.

Armatus is coming out in 2026 for Xbox Series consoles, PS5, PC, and Nintendo Switch 2. You can catch up on everything announced at today's Partner Showcase right here.

item.title: Major Borderlands 4 Update Adds Smarter Loot Drops, a New Legendary Loot Indicator for the Radar, and a Lot More
item.content:encoded:
Gearbox has released a significant patch for Borderlands 4 that makes some quality-of-life improvements such as smarter loot drops and a new Legendary Loot Indicator for your radar. These arrive alongside visual polish and stability updates for a “smoother” experience on Kairos, Gearbox said.

Digging into the detail, Class Mods have been adjusted to drop more for your current character, which is a welcome change for those on the hunt for ever-improving builds. The loot feed is now updated to display total current currency after spending or receiving money, and the likelihood of unintended movements or knockbacks while reviving a teammate is reduced. And it's worth noting that the patch adds a new Legendary Loot Indicator to the combat radar for easier identification of high-rarity drops. given how busy with loot Borderlands 4 can get, this is also welcome.

Borderlands 4: All Vault Hunter Skill Trees Ranked

Borderlands 4: All Vault Hunter Skill Trees Ranked

In the patch notes, below, Gearbox said it was wrapping up work on Photo Mode, while other updates like support for multiple active Big Encore Machines and more options for scaling difficulty are coming.

Further into the future, Gearbox said it’s looking at ways to improve shared character progression, add additional endgame-focused activities (Takedown), launch cross-save support, and more. Major Updates, which deliver larger-scale changes, are planned to deploy about a month apart.

Today’s update launches alongside Bounty Pack 1: How Rush Saved Mercenary Day, which is now free for all players. How Rush Saved Mercenary Day is the first of five post-launch DLC Bounty Packs coming to Borderlands 4. While How Rush Saved Mercenary Day is free for all players, Bounty Packs 2, 3, 4, and 5 are included with Borderlands 4 Deluxe Edition, Borderlands 4 Super Deluxe Edition, the Borderlands 4 Bounty Pack Bundle, and will be available for separate purchase.

Bounty Pack 1: How Rush Saved Mercenary Day

So in the spirit of the season, we're giving a gift to all Borderlands 4 players by making Bounty Pack 1 free! Thank you for all the passion and support you've given us as a community. We're hard at work making sure future Bounty Packs are more fully loaded with the compelling content players have been asking for. Playing Borderlands 4 with a Vault Card active gives you more loot and XP via Daily and Weekly challenges, and it can be leveled up at your own pace (no time limits or expiring rewards here). You can activate it via the Vault Card screen in your ECHO menu. Vault Card progression works just like leveling up: it's all driven by how much XP you're gaining. By exploring Kairos, killing enemies, and completing quests, you'll fill up your Vault Card progression in addition to your regular XP!
